{{Flagicon|Virginia}} 13th Battalion Virginia Light Artillery |commands = |battles = [[American Civil War]] |awards = }} '''Samuel Lightfoot Flournoy''' (November 25, 1846 – January 28, 1904) was an [[American people|American]] lawyer, politician, and businessperson in the [[U.S. state]] of [[West Virginia]]. Flournoy served as a [[state senator]] representing the 12th Senatorial District in the [[West Virginia Senate]] (1885–1890) and served three terms as mayor of [[Romney, West Virginia|Romney]], West Virginia. Flournoy unsuccessfully ran as a candidate for the [[West Virginia Democratic Party]] [[List of Governors of West Virginia|gubernatorial]] [[nomination]] in 1900. Flournoy was born in 1846 in [[Chesterfield County, Virginia|Chesterfield County]], [[Virginia]]. In 1863, during the [[American Civil War]], he [[Military service|enlisted]] as a [[Private (rank)|private]] in the [[Confederate States Army]] and served until the war's end in 1865. After graduating from [[Hampden–Sydney College]] in 1868, Flournoy taught school for four years while studying law. In 1870 he relocated to Romney, West Virginia, where he served as principal of the Potomac Academy. He was admitted to the bar in 1873, and afterward served on the Board of Regents for the [[West Virginia Schools for the Deaf and Blind]] (1876–1880). During his second term in the West Virginia Senate, Flournoy relocated to [[Charleston, West Virginia|Charleston]] to practice law. He also engaged in several business ventures and was an [[wikt:incorporator|incorporator]] of the Bank of Romney, the Tug and Guyandotte Railroad Company, the Bradford Building Company, the White Oak Mining Company, and the West Construction Company. Flournoy served on the Board of Trustees of Hampden–Sydney College from 1892 until his death in 1904. Through his marriage to Frances "Fannie" Ann Armstrong White, Flournoy was a brother-in-law of [[West Virginia Attorney General]] [[Robert White (attorney general)|Robert White]] and West Virginia Fish Commission President [[Christian Streit White]], and the son-in-law of [[Hampshire County, West Virginia|Hampshire County]] Clerk of Court [[John Baker White (Virginia)|John Baker White]]. Through his father, Flournoy was a relative of [[Thomas Flournoy]], [[United States House of Representatives|United States Representative]] from Virginia. Flournoy was the father of prominent Charleston lawyer [[Samuel Lightfoot Flournoy (West Virginia lawyer)|Samuel Lightfoot Flournoy]]. == Early life and military career == Samuel Lightfoot Flournoy was born on November 25, 1846, in [[Chesterfield County, Virginia|Chesterfield County]], [[Virginia]], {{convert|7|mi|km|0|adj=off}} from [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]], and was the son of Richard W. Flournoy and his wife, Sarah Parke Poindexter Flournoy.{{Harvnb|Atkinson|Gibbens|1890|p=442.}}{{Harvnb|Miller|Maxwell|1913|p=84.}}{{Harvnb|Maxwell|Swisher|1897|p=706.}}{{Harvnb|Virginia Historical Society|1912|p=331.}} He had four siblings, two brothers and two sisters: Reverend Parke Poindexter Flournoy, Eliza Flournoy Ayler, Richard W. Flournoy, and Ellen Flournoy Thornton. Flournoy was of [[English people|English]] and [[French people|French]] [[ancestry]]. He was a relative of [[Thomas Flournoy]], [[United States House of Representatives|United States Representative]] from Virginia.{{Harvnb|Henneman|1899a|p=294.}} The majority of Flournoy's youth and early adulthood were spent in Richmond, where he attended the city's public schools. In 1863, during the [[American Civil War]], Flournoy [[Military service|enlisted]] as a [[Private (rank)|private]] in the [[Confederate States Army]] at the age of 17. He served the entirety of his enlistment in Company A, Otey Battery, 13th Battalion, Virginia Light Artillery in Richmond, throughout the course of the war until its end in 1865. == Education and teaching career == Following the war, Flournoy entered [[Hampden–Sydney College]] in [[Hampden Sydney, Virginia|Hampden Sydney]], Virginia, to pursue an education in [[Classics|classical studies]]. His elder brother Parke Poindexter Flournoy had been an assistant professor at the college during the war.{{Harvnb|Henneman|1899b|p=363.}} Flournoy graduated with honors and a [[Bachelor of Arts]] from Hampden–Sydney College in 1868 and received the Speaker's Medal from the institution's Philanthropic Debating Society.{{Harvnb|Brown|1917|p=312.}} While attending Hampden–Sydney College, he was a member of the [[Beta Theta Pi]] [[Fraternities and sororities in North America|fraternity]]. Following graduation, Flournoy taught school for four years while studying [[Jurisprudence|law]]. Around 1870 he relocated to [[Romney, West Virginia|Romney]], [[West Virginia]], where he took charge as principal and taught at the Potomac Academy with "considerable success" and continued his law studies.{{Harvnb|Maxwell|Swisher|1897|p=300.}}{{Harvnb|Brown|1917|p=159.}}{{Harvnb|Maxwell|Swisher|1897|p=496.}} Flournoy was [[Admission to the bar in the United States|admitted to the bar]] in Romney in January 1873.{{Harvnb|Evans|1899|p=195.}} == Law and political careers == ===Romney law practice=== [[File:Old Hampshire County Courthouse Romney WV.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Hampshire County Courthouse (West Virginia)|Hampshire County Courthouse]] in [[Romney, West Virginia|Romney]]]] Following his admission to the bar, Flournoy immediately began [[practice of law|practicing law]] in Romney and "won merited distinction" in his field. He became a prominent leader in the community and was elected as a member of the [[Romney Literary Society]].{{Harvnb|Maxwell|Swisher|1897|p=436.}} Flournoy served on the fourth Board of Regents of the [[West Virginia Schools for the Deaf and Blind]] from 1876 to 1880.{{Harvnb|Maxwell|Swisher|1897|pp=478–479.}} He served three terms as [[mayor]] of Romney. As his law career prospered, Flournoy was active in the establishment of The Society of the Ex-Confederate Soldiers in Hampshire County.{{cite news| last =Spangler | first = Don | author-link =| title =Romney Man Owns Historic Document | newspaper = Cumberland Evening Times | publication-place = [[Cumberland, Maryland]] | volume = | issue = | date = August 5, 1974 | page = 6 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/3759495/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} The society's missions were to obtain an accurate roster of Confederate veterans and to collect and preserve materials to maintain a "truthful" history of the American Civil War. Flournoy and a group of Confederate veterans met at the [[Hampshire County Courthouse (West Virginia)|Hampshire County Courthouse]] in Romney on July 31, 1883, where he was appointed secretary of the society. The society's constitution was presented at its first annual reunion on September 5, 1883, at which time Flournoy was officially titled as the society's corresponding secretary. [[Alexander W. Monroe]] was among the society's three concurrently-serving vice presidents. === West Virginia Senate === Flournoy was elected to represent the 12th Senatorial District, consisting of [[Grant County, West Virginia|Grant]], [[Hampshire County, West Virginia|Hampshire]], [[Hardy County, West Virginia|Hardy]], [[Mineral County, West Virginia|Mineral]], and [[Pendleton County, West Virginia|Pendleton]] counties, in the [[West Virginia Senate]] in 1885 and was re-elected to the seat in 1889.{{Harvnb|Atkinson|Gibbens|1890|p=140.}}{{Harvnb|West Virginia Legislature|1922|p=272.}}{{Harvnb|Atkinson|Gibbens|1890|p=72.}}{{Harvnb|Munske|Kerns|2004|p=180.}} In the West Virginia state senatorial election on November 6, 1888, Flournoy defeated his [[West Virginia Republican Party|Republican]] challenger S. G. Pownall with 5,578 votes to Pownall's 4,028 votes. Following his election, Flournoy was selected as part of West Virginia's attending delegation to the inauguration of President [[Benjamin Harrison]].{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Washington's Inauguration. | newspaper = Pittsburgh Daily Post | publication-place = [[Pittsburgh]] | volume = | issue = | date = December 15, 1888 | page = 1 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/86389991/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =The Big Parade: And All the Other Features of the Celebration. | newspaper = [[Brooklyn Eagle|The Brooklyn Daily Eagle]] | publication-place = [[Brooklyn]] | volume = | issue = | date = April 23, 1889 | page = 6 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/50455598/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} In his first term in the West Virginia Senate, Flournoy served as [[chairman]] of the Judiciary Committee, and in his second term he served as chairman of the Committee on Counties and Municipal Corporations. Throughout his two terms, Flournoy served on the committees of Privileges and Elections, Federal Relations, Immigration and Agriculture, and Public Printing. In 1890, during his second term in the West Virginia Senate, Flournoy relocated from Romney to [[Charleston, West Virginia|Charleston]] and continued practicing law there. He resigned from his senate seat in 1890. === Charleston law practice=== In Charleston, in 1891, Flournoy founded the [[law firm]] Couch, Flournoy and Price with former [[President of the West Virginia Senate|West Virginia Senate President]], [[George E. Price|George Edmund Price]].{{Harvnb|Atkinson|1919|p=357.}}{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Exchange Echoes: Culled From the Columns of Our County Contemporaries | newspaper = The News | publication-place = [[Frederick, Maryland]] | volume = | issue = | date = June 5, 1891 | page = 4 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/8022089/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} The firm would later become Flournoy, Price, and Smith with the addition of Harrison Brooks Smith in 1894.{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Death of a Prominent Charleston Man. | newspaper = The Weekly Register | publication-place = [[Point Pleasant, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = February 3, 1904 | page = 3 | url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026817/1904-02-03/ed-1/seq-3/ | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | via = [[Chronicling America]]}} On March 7, 1892, Flournoy and his partner Price were admitted to practice before the [[Supreme Court of the United States]].{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Admitted to Practice. | newspaper = The Wheeling Daily Intelligencer | publication-place = [[Wheeling, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date =March 8, 1892 | page = 1 | url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026844/1892-03-08/ed-1/seq-1/ | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | via = [[Chronicling America]]}} Flournoy and Price continued to expand their law practice into [[Southern West Virginia]] when they were admitted to the bar of [[Summers County, West Virginia|Summers County]] in 1894.{{Harvnb|Miller|1908|p=770.}} In April 1897, while practicing law in Charleston, Flournoy became qualified to practice law at the bar of [[Tazewell County, Virginia]].{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Proceedings of Circuit Court | newspaper = Clinch Valley News | publication-place = [[Tazewell, Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date =April 16, 1897 | page = 3 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/79859108/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} As a Charleston lawyer, Flournoy represented both plaintiffs and defendants involved in suits over coalfield land titles in Southern West Virginia and [[Southwest Virginia]]. From 1900 to 1901, Flournoy represented the defendant Henry C. King in a widely publicized case involving claim to a land title of {{convert|500000|acres|km2}} spanning counties in Southern West Virginia and Southwest Virginia in the [[United States Circuit Court of Appeals]].{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =A Big Suit. | newspaper = [[The Virginian-Pilot]] | publication-place = [[Norfolk, Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = November 27, 1900 | page = 8 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/68126279/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =U.S. Circuit Court: One Case Took Up The Whole Time Of The Court Yesterday | newspaper = Richmond Dispatch | publication-place = [[Richmond, Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = November 8, 1901 | page = 2 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/92974819/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Day Consumed In Argument | newspaper = The Times | publication-place = [[Richmond, Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = November 8, 1901 | page = 6 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/81018090/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} In 1901, Flournoy represented S. J. Ritchie of [[Akron, Ohio]], in the Tazewell County Court, where his client claimed a large land tract of valuable coalfields spanning Tazewell County and [[McDowell County, West Virginia]].{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Town And County News. | newspaper = Tazewell Republican | publication-place = [[Tazewell, Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date =August 1, 1901 | page = 4 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/64301665/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} === Gubernatorial candidacy === In early April 1900, a movement among prominent [[West Virginia Democratic Party]] members in Charleston began to coalesce around Flournoy in support of his candidacy for West Virginia governor.{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =West Virginia Democrats: A Movement to Nominate Flournoy for Governor. | newspaper = Richmond Dispatch | publication-place = [[Richmond, Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = April 17, 1900 | page = 6 | url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038614/1900-04-17/ed-1/seq-6/ | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | via = [[Chronicling America]]}}{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Announcements. | newspaper = Spirit of Jefferson | publication-place = [[Charles Town, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date =April 17, 1900 | page = 2 | url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026788/1900-04-17/ed-1/seq-2/ | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | via = [[Chronicling America]]}} Flournoy was considered a [[William Jennings Bryan]] Democrat with conservative positions, and Charleston Democrats felt he would receive wide support and would not antagonize corporations. Flournoy took the matter under advisement and on April 25, 1900, he announced his candidacy for West Virginia governor.{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Flournoy Formally Announces Candidacy for Governor.| newspaper = Richmond Dispatch | publication-place = [[Richmond, Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = April 28, 1900 | page = 3 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/77831871/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}{{cite news| last = Special Dispatch | first = | author-link =| title =Clans Assembling: West Virginia Democrats Arriving at Parkersburg. Claims of the Candidates: Do Not Concede Anything to Any of Their Opponents. | newspaper = [[Baltimore Morning Herald]] | publication-place = Baltimore | volume = | issue = | date = June 5, 1900 | page = | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TxlFAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BbsMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2878,6266491&dq=samuel-flournoy&hl=en | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | via = [[Google News Archive]] }} In his announcement, Flournoy stated that he was unwilling to engage in a heated contest for the nomination and that he would be content with the outcome of the Democratic Party state convention, no matter the decision.{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Announcements. | newspaper = Spirit of Jefferson | publication-place = [[Charles Town, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date =May 1, 1900 | page = 2 | url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026788/1900-05-01/ed-1/seq-2/ | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | via = [[Chronicling America]]}} He further stated that he trusted the state convention would craft a ticket that would command the support of the people of West Virginia. Following his announcement, the ''Spirit of Jefferson'' newspaper in [[Charles Town, West Virginia|Charles Town]] stated of Flournoy on May 1, 1900: "Mr. Flournoy is a most estimable gentleman, well and favorably known here, would doubtless make an excellent governor, and as the nominee of the Democratic party would receive a hearty support in the Eastern panhandle." Flournoy also received the support of the Democratic Party in [[Mineral County, West Virginia|Mineral County]] in May 1900.{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Items of Interest. | newspaper = Spirit of Jefferson | publication-place = [[Charles Town, West Virginia]] | volume = XXXV | issue = 19 | date =May 8, 1900 | page = 1 | url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026788/1900-05-08/ed-1/seq-1/ | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | via = [[Chronicling America]]}} At the West Virginia Democratic Party State Convention held in [[Parkersburg, West Virginia|Parkersburg]] on June 6, 1900, Flournoy competed for the party's nomination for gubernatorial candidacy against Lewis N. Tavenner of Parkersburg, John H. Holt of [[Huntington, West Virginia|Huntington]], and Virgil G. Lewis of [[Mason City, West Virginia|Mason City]].{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =West Virginia Democrats: Nominate John H. Holt For Governor On the First Ballot. | newspaper = [[The Courier-Journal]] | publication-place = [[Louisville, Kentucky]] | volume = | issue = | date = June 7, 1900 | page = 3 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/31359970/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =West Virginia Democrats: Scenes of Disorder Mark Balloting for Governor. | newspaper = [[Lincoln Journal Star|Nebraska State Journal]] | publication-place = [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | volume = | issue = | date = June 7, 1900 | page = 2 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/37033980/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} Prior to the convention, [[Daniel B. Lucas]] of [[Jefferson County, West Virginia|Jefferson County]] had been a candidate for nomination.{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Politics. | newspaper = The Wheeling Daily Intelligencer | publication-place = [[Wheeling, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date =June 4, 1900 | page = 2 | url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026844/1900-06-04/ed-1/seq-2/ | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | via = [[Chronicling America]]}} Holt won the Democratic Party's nomination on the first ballot, but lost in the [[General election (U.S.)|general election]] to [[Republican Party of West Virginia|Republican]] candidate [[Albert B. White]]. Flournoy and Lewis each received just one vote while Holt received 483 and Tavenner received 450 votes.{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =J. H. Holt for Governor: Choice of the West Virginia State Democratic Convention | newspaper = [[The Washington Star|Evening Star]] | publication-place = [[Washington, D.C.]] | volume = | issue = | date =June 7, 1900 | page = 2 | url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1900-06-07/ed-1/seq-2/ | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | via = [[Chronicling America]]}} === West Virginia Bar Association === Flournoy was present at the first meeting of the West Virginia Bar Association held on the date of its organization on July 8, 1886, in [[Grafton, West Virginia|Grafton]].{{Harvnb|West Virginia Bar Association|1886|p=13.}}{{cite news| last = Special Dispatch | first = | author-link =| title =State Bar Association, Formed at Grafton Yesterday - The Officers Elected. | newspaper = [[The Intelligencer & Wheeling News Register|The Wheeling Intelligencer]] | publication-place = [[Wheeling, West Virginia|Wheeling]], [[West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = July 9, 1886 | page = | url = http://www.wvculture.org/history/organizations/wvbar01.html | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150213052757/http://www.wvculture.org/history/organizations/wvbar01.html | archive-date=February 13, 2015}} As a member, Flournoy was appointed to draft the association's [[constitution]] and [[by-law]]s and served on its executive committee.{{Harvnb|West Virginia Bar Association|1886|p=14.}}{{Harvnb|West Virginia Bar Association|1886|p=18.}} In addition to serving as a vice president of the association, Flournoy also represented the 12th Judicial Circuit on the association's Committee on Judicial Administration and Legal Reform and later served on the Committee of Admissions.{{Harvnb|West Virginia Bar Association|1886|pp=3–5.}} On January 7, 1892, Flournoy was elected as the association's vice president for [[West Virginia's 3rd congressional district]].{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =The Bar Association: Interesting Session – Officers Elected – Banquet Closes the Meeting. | newspaper = The Wheeling Daily Intelligencer | publication-place = [[Wheeling, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date =June 4, 1900 | page = 2 | url = http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026844/1900-06-04/ed-1/seq-2/ | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | via = [[Chronicling America]]}} == Business pursuits == In addition to his law practice and political pursuits, Flournoy also engaged in several business ventures. On August 4, 1888, he purchased five shares priced at $100 each in order to invest in and provide [[Stock|capital stock]] for the [[Incorporation (business)|incorporation]] of the Bank of Romney.{{Harvnb|West Virginia Legislature|1889|pp=579–581.}} Along with Harrison B. Smith and fellow state senator George E. Price, Flournoy again served as an [[wikt:incorporator|incorporator]] on April 25, 1901, when the Tug and Guyandotte Railroad Company was granted its charter with $100,000 in capital.{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =A New Road Chartered: The Tug and Guyandotte Line Gets a West Virginia Franchise. | newspaper = Richmond Dispatch | publication-place = [[Richmond, Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = April 26, 1901 | page = 6 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/92963289/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} The Tug and Guyandotte Railroad was constructed between the [[Norfolk and Western Railway]] at [[Davy, West Virginia|Davy]] and [[Baileysville, West Virginia|Baileysville]] to facilitate the transportation of coal. Flournoy, Price, and Flournoy's son Richard Parke Flournoy were incorporators of the Bradford Building Company which was chartered with capital of $20,000 on September 25, 1901, with the purpose of engaging in general building and construction projects.{{Harvnb|Office of the Governor of West Virginia|1903|p=62.}} The following year, on December 20, 1902, Flournoy, Price, and their law partner Smith were also incorporators of the White Oak Mining Company and of the West Construction Company.{{Harvnb|Office of the Governor of West Virginia|1903|p=320.}}{{Harvnb|Office of the Governor of West Virginia|1903|p=311.}} With an authorized capital stock of $100,000, the White Oak Mining Company, that was engaged in the mining, shipment, and sale of coal, the cutting and sawing of timber, and the operations and sales of railway, telephone, and telegraph lines and networks. The West Construction Company, based in [[Chattanooga, Tennessee|Chattanooga]], [[Tennessee]], was a general contracting and construction firm also involved in the operation and maintenance of railway, telephone, and telegraph lines. ==Personal life== ===Marriage and children=== On April 10, 1875, in Hampshire County, Flournoy married Frances "Fannie" Ann Armstrong White (April 10, 1844 – February 25, 1922), the daughter of Hampshire County Clerk of Court [[John Baker White (Virginia)|John Baker White]] and his wife Frances Ann Streit White.{{Harvnb|Miller|Maxwell|1913|p=85.}}{{cite web | url = http://www.wvculture.org/vrr/va_mcdetail.aspx?Id=10996322 | title = Marriage Record Detail: Samuel Lightfoot Flournoy | work = West Virginia Vital Research Records | publisher = West Virginia Division of Culture and History | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151007123438/http://www.wvculture.org/vrr/va_mcdetail.aspx?Id=10996322 | archive-date = October 7, 2015}}{{cite web | url = http://www.wvculture.org/vrr/va_dcdetail.aspx?Id=160937 | title = Death Record Detail: Fannie A. Flournoy | work = West Virginia Vital Research Records | publisher = West Virginia Division of Culture and History | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150722075236/http://www.wvculture.org/vrr/va_dcdetail.aspx?Id=160937 | archive-date=July 22, 2015}} Frances White's brother, [[Robert White (attorney general)|Robert White]], served as [[List of West Virginia Attorneys General|West Virginia Attorney General]], and her brother [[Christian Streit White]] served as President of the West Virginia Fish Commission. Flournoy and his wife Frances had six children (five sons and one daughter): *Richard Parke Flournoy (December 29, 1875 – May 5, 1959){{cite web | url = http://www.wvculture.org/vrr/va_dcdetail.aspx?Id=2589792 | title = Death Record Detail: R. Parke Flournoy | work = West Virginia Vital Research Records | publisher = West Virginia Division of Culture and History | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | archive-url = http://www.webcitation.org/6c6KONzWt | archive-date = October 7, 2015}}{{cite web | url = http://www.wvculture.org/vrr/va_bcdetail.aspx?Id=3329654 | title = Birth Record Detail: Richard Parke Flournoy | work = West Virginia Vital Research Records | publisher = West Virginia Division of Culture and History | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151007123827/http://www.wvculture.org/vrr/va_bcdetail.aspx?Id=3329654 | archive-date = October 7, 2015}} *Harry Lightfoot Flournoy (March 4, 1878 – December 31, 1954){{cite web | url = http://www.wvculture.org/vrr/va_dcdetail.aspx?Id=53855 | title = Death Record Detail: Harry L. https://web.archive.org/web/20151007124306/http://www.wvculture.org/vrr/va_mcdetail.aspx?Id=12580826 }} === Religious activities === Flournoy was active in the [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterian Church]] in Hampshire County and served as a [[trustee]] for the [[Presbyterian polity#Presbytery|Presbytery]] of Winchester, along with [[Henry Bell Gilkeson]].{{Harvnb|Woodworth|1947|p=369.}} In 1881, Flournoy and his fellow trustees were instrumental in securing from Amos L. and Allie G. Pugh a house and a large partially [[Woodland|wooded]] [[land lot|lot]] in [[Capon Bridge, West Virginia|Capon Bridge]] for use by the Presbytery as a centrally located [[manse]] in Hampshire County. Flournoy was elected as a [[deacon]] in the Presbyterian Church in 1879 and remained a trustee of the Presbytery of Winchester until 1891 when he relocated to Charleston.{{Harvnb|Woodworth|1947|p=385.}} Following his move to Charleston, Flournoy became a member of the First Presbyterian Church and served as one of seven church elders there.{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =First Presbyterian To Honor Dr. Thompson: Completes Twenty Years of Service as Pastor, Coming Here in 1902 | newspaper = [[Charleston Daily Mail]] | publication-place = [[Charleston, West Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = November 12, 1922 | page = 7 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/16465001/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} === Later life and death=== Flounoy died as a result of throat and pulmonary illnesses on January 28, 1904, at 2:40 a.m. in [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]], [[Florida]], where he had traveled to restore his failing health.{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Obituary: S. L. Flournoy | newspaper = [[Richmond Times-Dispatch|The Times-Dispatch]] | publication-place = [[Richmond, Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = January 29, 1904 | page = 5 | url =http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038615/1904-01-29/ed-1/seq-5/ | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | via = [[Chronicling America]]}}{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Local Department: Personals. | newspaper = Staunton Spectator and Vindicator | publication-place = [[Staunton, Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = February 12, 1904 | page = 3 | url = https://www.newspapers.com/image/72117589/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} His wife and his physician Dr. Henry were at his side at the time of his death. Flournoy was survived by his wife, and five of his children. He served on the [[Board of directors|Board of Trustees]] of Hampden–Sydney College from 1892 until his death.{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Hampden–Sidney: Commencement Exercises–The Board Tables Request to Remove Restrictions on Dancing. | newspaper = Richmond Times | publication-place = [[Richmond, Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = April 28, 1900 | page = 11 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/image/81012761/ | accessdate =October 7, 2015 | via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} A tribute to Flournoy was rendered by college president [[Richard McIlwaine (educator)|Richard McIlwaine]] at a meeting of the Hampden–Sydney College trustees on June 13, 1904.{{cite news| last = | first = | author-link =| title =Hampden–Sidney: Final Exercises and Conferring of Degrees and Medals. | newspaper = [[Richmond Times-Dispatch|The Times-Dispatch]] | publication-place = [[Richmond, Virginia]] | volume = | issue = | date = June 15, 1904 | page = 3 | url =http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038615/1904-06-15/ed-1/seq-3/ | accessdate = October 7, 2015 | via = [[Chronicling America]]}} Following his death, ''The Weekly Register'' newspaper in [[Point Pleasant, West Virginia|Point Pleasant]] remarked that Flournoy "was one of the prominent [Democratic] leaders of the state, and occupied a high place in the estimation [of] the party followers".
